citing_paper_authors: Ryan, McDonald | Fernando, Pereira | Kiril, Ribarov | Jan, Hajič
raw_text: Most previous dependency parsing models have focused on projective trees, including the work of Eisner (1996), Collins et al (1999), Yamada and Matsumoto (2003), Nivre and Scholz (2004), and McDonald et al (2005)
clean_text: Most previous dependency parsing models have focused on projective trees, including the work of Eisner (1996), Collins et al (1999), Yamada and Matsumoto (2003), Nivre and Scholz (2004), and McDonald et al (2005).

raw_text: In this paper wefill a gap in the CCG literature by developing a shift reduce parser for CCG.Shift-reduce parsers have become popular for dependency parsing, building on the initial work of Yamada and Matsumoto (2003) and Nivre and Scholz (2004)
clean_text: In this paper we fill a gap in the CCG literature by developing a shift reduce parser for CCG. Shift-reduce parsers have become popular for dependency parsing, building on the initial work of Yamada and Matsumoto (2003) and Nivre and Scholz (2004).

citing_paper_authors: Johan, Hall | Joakim, Nivre | Jens, Nilsson

clean_text: It was extended to labeled dependency parsing by Nivre et al (2004) (for Swedish) and Nivre and Scholz (2004) (for English).

citing_paper_authors: Johan, Hall | Joakim, Nivre | Jens, Nilsson
raw_text: Memory-based learning (MBL), which is based on the idea that learning is the simple storage of experiences in memory and that solving a new problem is achieved by reusing solutions from similar previously solved problems (Daelemans and Van den Bosch, 2005), has been used primarily by Nivre et al (2004), Nivre and Scholz (2004), and Sagae and Lavie (2005)
clean_text: Memory-based learning (MBL), which is based on the idea that learning is the simple storage of experiences in memory and that solving a new problem is achieved by reusing solutions from similar previously solved problems (Daelemans and Van den Bosch, 2005), has been used primarily by Nivre et al (2004), Nivre and Scholz (2004), and Sagae and Lavie (2005).

raw_text: To constrain our reorderings, we first produce a parse tree, using a dependency parser similar to that of Nivre and Scholz (2004)
clean_text: To constrain our reorderings, we first produce a parse tree, using a dependency parser similar to that of Nivre and Scholz (2004).

raw_text: Nivre and Scholz (2004) proposed a variant of the model of Yamada and Matsumoto that reduces the complexity, from the worst case quadratic to linear
clean_text: Nivre and Scholz (2004) proposed a variant of the model of Yamada and Matsumoto that reduces the complexity, from the worst case quadratic to linear.

raw_text: For instance, Nivre and Scholz presented a deterministic dependency parser trained by memory-based learning (NivreandScholz, 2004)
clean_text: For instance, Nivre and Scholz presented a deterministic dependency parser trained by memory-based learning (Nivre and Scholz, 2004).

raw_text: We built a parser based on the deterministic algorithm of Nivre and Scholz (Nivre and Scholz, 2004) as a base dependency parser
clean_text: We built a parser based on the deterministic algorithm of Nivre and Scholz (Nivre and Scholz, 2004) as a base dependency parser.

raw_text: The deterministic shift/reduce classifier-based dependency parsing approach (Nivre and Scholz,2004) has been shown to offer state-of-the-art accuracy (Nivre et al, 2006) with high efficiency due to a greedy search strategy
clean_text: The deterministic shift/reduce classifier-based dependency parsing approach (Nivre and Scholz,2004) has been shown to offer state-of-the-art accuracy (Nivre et al, 2006) with high efficiency due to a greedy search strategy.

raw_text: Nivre? s parser has been tested for Swedish (Nivre et al, 2004), English (Nivre and Scholz, 2004), Czech (Nivre and Nilsson, 2005), Bulgarian (Marinov and Nivre, 2005) and Chinese Cheng et al (2005), while McDonald? s parser has been applied to English (McDonald et al, 2005a), Czech (McDonald et al, 2005b) and, very recently, Danish (McDonald and Pereira, 2006)
clean_text: Nivre's parser has been tested for Swedish (Nivre et al, 2004), English (Nivre and Scholz, 2004), Czech (Nivre and Nilsson, 2005), Bulgarian (Marinov and Nivre, 2005) and Chinese Cheng et al (2005), while McDonald? s parser has been applied to English (McDonald et al, 2005a), Czech (McDonald et al, 2005b) and, very recently, Danish (McDonald and Pereira, 2006).

raw_text: Nivre and Scholz (2004) uses this term with reference to Yamada and Matsumoto (2003), whose parser has to find all children of a token before it can attach that token to its head. We will refer to this as? bottom-up-trees?
clean_text: Nivre and Scholz (2004) uses this term with reference to Yamada and Matsumoto (2003), whose parser has to find all children of a token before it can attach that token to its head. We will refer to this as bottom-up-trees.

raw_text: Johansson and Nugues (2006 )describea non-deterministic implementation to the dependency parser outlined by Nivre and Scholz (2004), where they apply an n-best beam search strategy. For a highly constrained unification-based formalism like HPSG, a deterministic parsing strategy could frequently lead to parse failures
clean_text: Johansson and Nugues (2006) describe a non-deterministic implementation to the dependency parser outlined by Nivre and Scholz (2004), where they apply an n-best beam search strategy. For a highly constrained unification-based formalism like HPSG, a deterministic parsing strategy could frequently lead to parse failures.

raw_text: We present a statistical parser that is based on a shift-reduce algorithm, like the parsers of Sagae and Lavie (2005) and Nivre and Scholz (2004), but performs a best-first search instead of pursuing a single analysis path in deterministic fashion
clean_text: We present a statistical parser that is based on a shift-reduce algorithm, like the parsers of Sagae and Lavie (2005) and Nivre and Scholz (2004), but performs a best-first search instead of pursuing a single analysis path in deterministic fashion.

raw_text: That algorithm, in turn, is similar to the dependency parsing algorithm of Nivre and Scholz (2004), but it builds a constituent tree and a dependency tree simultaneously
clean_text: That algorithm, in turn, is similar to the dependency parsing algorithm of Nivre and Scholz (2004), but it builds a constituent tree and a dependency tree simultaneously.

citing_paper_authors: Shisanu, Tongchim | Virach, Sornlertlamvanich | Hitoshi, Isahara
raw_text: The dependency structure for Thai is more flexible than some languages like Japanese (Sekine et al, 2000), Turkish (Eryigit and Oflazer, 2006), while it is close to Chinese (Cheng et al, 2005) and English (Nivre and Scholz, 2004)
clean_text: The dependency structure for Thai is more flexible than some languages like Japanese (Sekine et al, 2000), Turkish (Eryigit and Oflazer, 2006), while it is close to Chinese (Cheng et al, 2005) and English (Nivre and Scholz, 2004).

citing_paper_authors: Wenduan, Xu | Stephen, Clark | Yue, Zhang
raw_text: Compared with greedy local-search (Nivre and Scholz, 2004), the use of a beam allows the parser to explore a larger search space and delay difficult ambiguity-resolving decisions by considering multiple items in parallel
clean_text: Compared with greedy local-search (Nivre and Scholz, 2004), the use of a beam allows the parser to explore a larger search space and delay difficult ambiguity-resolving decisions by considering multiple items in parallel.

raw_text: Features Used for Selecting Reduce The features used in (Nivre and Scholz, 2004) to define a state transition are basically obtained from the two target words wi and wj, and their related words
clean_text: Features Used for Selecting Reduce The features used in (Nivre and Scholz, 2004) to define a state transition are basically obtained from the two target words wi and wj, and their related words.

citing_paper_authors: Yue, Zhang | Byung-Gyu, Ahn | Stephen, Clark | Curt, Van Wyk | James R., Curran | Laura, Rimell
raw_text: There are dependency parsers that operate orders of magnitude faster, by exploiting the fact that accurate dependency parsing can be achieved by using a shift-reduce linear-time process which makes asingle decision at each point in the parsing process (Nivre and Scholz, 2004) .In this paper we focus on the Combinatory Categorial Grammar (CCG) parser of Clark and Cur ran (2007)
clean_text: There are dependency parsers that operate orders of magnitude faster, by exploiting the fact that accurate dependency parsing can be achieved by using a shift-reduce linear-time process which makes a single decision at each point in the parsing process (Nivre and Scholz, 2004). In this paper we focus on the Combinatory Categorial Grammar (CCG) parser of Clark and Curran (2007).
